medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent right upper quadrant pain with failure of antacid medical therapy. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Normal esophageal gastroduodenoscopy. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with bile aspirate. ANESTHESIA: IV Demerol and Versed in titrated fashion. INDICATIONS: This 41-year-old female presents to surgical office with history of recurrent right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Despite antacid therapy, the patient's pain has continued. Additional findings were concerning with possibility of a biliary etiology. The patient was explained the risks and benefits of an EGD as well as a Meltzer-Lyon test where upon bile aspiration was performed. The patient agreed to the procedure and informed consent was obtained. GROSS FINDINGS: No evidence of neoplasia, mucosal change, or ulcer on examination. Aspiration of the bile was done after the administration of 3 mcg of Kinevac. PROCEDURE DETAILS: The patient was placed in the supine position. After appropriate anesthesia was obtained, an Olympus gastroscope inserted from the oropharynx through the second portion of duodenum. Prior to this, 3 mcg of IV Kinevac was given to the patient to aid with the stimulation of bile. At this time, the patient as well complained of epigastric discomfort and nausea. This pain was similar to her previous pain. Bile was aspirated with a trap to enable the collection of the fluid. This fluid was then sent to lab for evaluation for crystals. Next, photodocumentation obtained and retraction of the gastroscope through the antrum revealed no other evidence of disease, retroflexion revealed no evidence of hiatal hernia or other mass and after straightening the scope and aspiration ________, gastroscope was retracted. The gastroesophageal junction was noted at 20 cm. No other evidence of disease was appreciated here. Retraction of the gastroscope backed through the esophagus, off the oropharynx, removed from the patient. The patient tolerated the procedure well. We will await evaluation of bile aspirate.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: The patient had repeated pain in the right upper part of the belly that did not get better with antacid medicine.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: The stomach and upper small intestine looked normal when examined.  

PROCEDURE PERFORMED: An upper endoscopy (EGD) was done and bile was taken for testing.  

ANESTHESIA: The patient received small, controlled doses of IV Demerol and Versed.  

INDICATIONS: A 41‑year‑old woman came to the surgical office because she has had repeated pain in the right upper belly. Antacids had not helped. Doctors suspected something in the bile ducts might be the cause. She was told about the risks and benefits of an EGD and a Meltzer‑Lyon test, which involves taking a bile sample. She agreed to the procedure and gave informed consent.  

GROSS FINDINGS: No tumors, abnormal lining, or ulcers were seen. Bile was collected after giving 3 mcg of Kinevac.  

PROCEDURE DETAILS: The patient lay on her back. After anesthesia, an Olympus scope was passed through her mouth, down her esophagus, and into the second part of the duodenum. Before the scope was inserted, 3 mcg of IV Kinevac was given to help stimulate bile flow. The patient felt discomfort and nausea in the upper belly, similar to her usual pain. Bile was drawn into a trap for collection and sent to the lab to check for crystals. Images were taken. The scope was pulled back through the stomach’s antrum and no disease was seen. The scope was turned back to look at the upper part of the stomach and no hiatal hernia or mass was found. After straightening the scope and taking a final sample, it was withdrawn. The gastroesophageal junction was at 20 cm. No other problems were seen. The scope was pulled back through the esophagus, out of the mouth, and removed. The patient tolerated the procedure well. We will wait for the bile test results.
